Barium Chloride is really a water disolveable salt. If barium chloride touches sodium sulphate it seems to lose its capability. That is explained by the substance reaction relating to the two ingredients.

Molecular situation:

BaCl2(aq) & Na2SO4(aq)-> BaSO4(s) + 2NaCl(aq)

ionic formula:

Ba+2(aq) and up. 2Cl-(aq) and 2Na+(aq) plus SO4-2(aq) -> BaSO4(s) & 2Na+(aq)+2Cl-(aq)

Such reactions display that when in contact with sodium sulphate, often the barium chloride dissolves towards BaSO4 which is an inadmissible substance along with NaCl. Thus, it can will no longer act on the exact muscle. In which type of antagonism is called Chemical Antagonism therefore refers to the circumstances when couple of substances merge in alternative; as a result, the consequence of the lively drug (in this case typically the barium chloride) is lost.
